pr_title: SONARJAVA-3564 Implement intersects and supersetOf helper for regex automata

timeline.message: SONARJAVA-3564 RegexParser set activeFlags on group and character AutomatonState

timeline.bodyText: It probably makes sense to initialize activeFlags in the constructor rather than parse and to get rid of initialFlags altogether (this would also entail getting rid of RegexParseResult.initialFlags, which should be fine because we can just use parseResult.getResult().activeFlags() instead).
timeline.author: sebastian-hungerecker-sonarsource

replies.bodyText: I removed the field initialFlags but keept the getter getInitialFlags().
replies.author: alban-auzeill

timeline.bodyText: If we decide to remove RegexParseResult.initialFlags, RegexTrees should never use FLAGS_HAVE_NO_EFFECT_ON_THIS_STATE.
timeline.author: sebastian-hungerecker-sonarsource

replies.bodyText: I have set correct activeFlags on all AutomatonState and removed FLAGS_HAVE_NO_EFFECT_ON_THIS_STATE
replies.author: alban-auzeill

SONARJAVA-3550 Rule S5994: Regex patterns following a possessive quantifier should not always fail

timeline.bodyText:
This doesn't really test what I wanted to test. The intent was to have a regex where the reluctantly quantified bit is subject to a flag, but the part after the reluctant quantifier is not. Previously the flag wouldn't have been taken into account in that case because it called flagActive for both arguments after both have been parsed. With the new system, both arguments should have accurate flags.
So to test this with the features we currently support, (?U:\\s*?)\u202F would be an example of a current FN that should be fixed by the change in how flags are tracked.
timeline.author: sebastian-hungerecker-sonarsource

replies.bodyText:
Unfortunately ReluctantQuantifierCheck only supports DOT and ESCAPED_CHARACTER_CLASS before the *?, and only PLAIN_CHARACTER, ESCAPED_CHARACTER_CLASS, CHARACTER_CLASS after.
So it was not possible to have different active flags before and after *?. For this, I had to change the rule implementation 😞 to support NON_CAPTURING_GROUP.
See this commit: SONARJAVA-3564 ReluctantQuantifierCheck support mixed active flags
replies.author: alban-auzeill

timeline.bodyText: Should be Character.MAX_CODE_POINT without the - 1 unless I'm missing something.
timeline.author: sebastian-hungerecker-sonarsource
sebastian-hungerecker-sonarsource

timeline.bodyText: If that only contains unknown characters and this is empty, the result should still be true false even if the default answer is true. So return !isEmpty() || !that.containsUnknownCharacters;.
timeline.author: sebastian-hungerecker-sonarsource

timeline.bodyText: There's a bug here if that ends with a range that goes up to MAX_CODE_POINT (inclusive), in which case the last entry of that.contents won't be a null entry. I've fixed the same bug for intersects in my PR.
timeline.author: sebastian-hungerecker-sonarsource

timeline.bodyText: I believe we should still report the issue if the continuation is not a RegexSyntaxElement. If the non-regex-syntax continuation has a single successor (i.e. it's not a branch), we can just report on that successor instead (or, if it's still not a regex syntax element, keep following single edges until we find one or a branch). And if it's a branch (as might be the case for something like (xx++)+x) we should probably still report by only reporting on the repetition itself with the message adjusted accordingly.
timeline.author: sebastian-hungerecker-sonarsource
